title: Untitled
text:
China has developed a deep-sea device capable of cutting armored undersea cables that carry 95% of global internet traffic. The tool, built for crewed and uncrewed submersibles, can operate at depths of 13,123 feet—twice the depth of most subsea infrastructure.

Though billed as a resource development tool, experts warn it could be used to target critical chokepoints like Guam, risking global communication outages. The diamond-tipped cutter runs on low power and is precise enough for stealth use by robotic arms.

The South China Sea tool adds to China’s expanding undersea dominance, raising fresh security concerns.

images.title: Blake, Wm. The First Book of Urizen, object 2. 1794.
